supportDesc.collation: a4–3 (2–4 canc.), 1–1810, 1910–1 (10 canc.), 204–1 (4 canc.), b4–3 (1–3 canc.) Gathering 20 is an addition (with thinner parchment). Most gatherings have catchwords added in ink at the bottom of the final page (many trimmed). eadem est que et totius libri
supportDesc.condition: Part of fol. 190 cut away to remove a drawing.

layoutDesc.layout: Fols. 1r–178v pricked on all edges of the page for border and line spacing (4 mm); ruled in pencil. The psalms text is written in a slightly larger script (but using same line spacing as commentary) and is cut into the column as needed, taking half of the column width, with ruling providing a guide.

Fols. 179r–184r have canticle text in larger script on every other line, in the second column from the inner edge of the page (slightly wider than the other three). Interlinear and marginal glosses added as needed, taking inconsistent amounts of space. Ruled in pencil, pricked on all edges of page, line spacing 4 mm.

Fols. 184v–188r write commentary continuously, with Creed text written in a larger script every other line, using the full column width. Fol. 184v uses same ruling as canticle glosses, with inner column thinner than the outer two. Ruled in pencil, pricked on all edges of page, line spacing 4 mm.
Fols. 188v–192r contain additions not planned as part of the original book. Ruled in plummet for line spacing of 4–5 mm, with margins varying significantly on each page. Not pricked.

handDesc.handNote: Fols. 1r–188r written in gothic textualis, first half of the thirteenth century, with contemporary corrections pencilled in the margins (e.g. fols. 39v, 44r–45r, 74r–77r). At least two scribes, one writing a smaller, more delicate script.
Fols. 188v–192r written in a charter hand, first half of the thirteenth century, at least two scribes.

decoDesc.decoNote: Fols. 1r–188r: Arabesque initials open prologue (12-line) and commentary (11-line), red and blue, decorated with penwork, also added to borders on some pages. Each text being commented on opens with an initial filling the margin, usually decorated with penwork, while new sections are indicated with simpler enlarged initials; both alternate between red and blue. Extra decorations added to the margin in several places, e.g. fols. 86r, 178v.
Fols. 188v–192r open new texts with a simple enlarged initial in red, except for fol. 188v, with a two-line initial in green

additions.p: Psalms commentary includes many marginal notations in a thirteenth-century textualis and fourtheenth-century cursive.
